We must continue, on this Juneteenth and every day, to recommit ourselves and our agenda to the fight for justice in all its forms, and to the movement for Black liberation.

I‚Äôm proud that last year, my legislation recognizing Juneteenth as a federal holiday was signed into law‚Äîbut the truth is that marking a day on the calendar and calling it a job well done is simply not enough.
There is racial injustice in our courts, our schools, our hospitals, our workplaces, the air we breathe, the water we drink, our blocks, neighborhoods, towns, and cities.

We must understand that Black people in the United States of America have never been fully freed, and that white supremacy and systemic racial injustice continue to plague our society from top to bottom.

It is a reminder that the struggle for racial justice in this country has too-often been delayed and unfulfilled, and that the true story of this nation has been hidden and diminished as we fail to reckon with our past head-on.

Juneteenth is a reminder of America‚Äôs original sin of slavery‚Äîa day to reflect on our nation‚Äôs shared, painful history, as well as the work we still have to do in order to make equality and justice a reality for all.

We can combat the rental crisis and the climate crisis at the same time and meet our responsibility as a nation to guarantee housing as a human right.

Revamping public housing will:
-Improve health, safety, and living conditions for nearly 2 million people. 
-Cut our carbon consumption and reduce public housing energy bills by up to 70% 
-Create over 200,000 new jobs
Our country has not added new public housing in decades. And our current public housing infrastructure is deteriorating and largely has not been updated since 1975.

The rental crisis is not new. Nearly half of all renter households were struggling with payments before the coronavirus pandemic. 

We need long-term, permanent solutions to provide affordable housing.

We need a Green New Deal for public housing.

Our country is on the brink of an unprecedented eviction crisis. 20 million people nationwide are struggling to make rent payments and are at risk of losing their homes. We must extend the national eviction moratorium and provide urgently needed rental assistance.

We have a responsibility to stand with the disability community and demand justice. Together we can and will build a more inclusive, equitable, and accessible country.

When it comes time for elections, the disability community faces extraordinary barriers to exercising their right to vote. Most polling places are not ADA compliant. This is voter suppression. Equal access to our democracy is non-negotiable.

This pandemic has been challenging for students and families across the country. But the burden falls even greater on students with disabilities, who are being denied the services they need during this crisis. We cannot continue to let these students fall between the cracks.

The sub-minimum wage is a legal loophole that allows organizations to pay workers with disabilities a fraction of what their non-disabled coworkers are paid‚Äîeven below the federal minimum wage. We must end this injustice and raise the minimum wage to at least $15 for all people.

About one third to one half of all people killed by police have a disability. When we talk about addressing systemic racism and police brutality, it is crucial that the disability community is central to and included in the conversation. #BlackDisabledLivesMatter
Advocacy for the disability community cannot stop at simply expanding accessibility. We must fight to guarantee racial, social, and economic justice for all.

This Sunday, we marked the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act. This act codified important rights for people with disabilities. But the ADA in its current form is not enough to provide the disability community with the protections and resources they need.

Today is the last day of Disability Pride Month. We celebrate the disability activists who fought to pass the monumental Americans with Disabilities Act and honor their work by continuing the fight to expand disability rights. This is a year round struggle.

The Nuclear Freeze Movement began the end of the arms race. It was regular people concerned about their communities, their children, the future of our country and our planet who rose up, organized, demanded change, and won.
It changed the whole tenor of negotiations between the United States and the USSR. It drove Ronald Reagan back to the negotiating table.
On May 4, 1983, the Nuclear Freeze Resolution passed the House with broad bipartisan support. By 1984 it was a part of the Democratic Presidential Party Platform.

By the fall of 1982, nuclear freeze referenda appeared on the ballot in 10 states and 37 cities and counties across the country. In all but 1 of the states and 3 of the localities, voters delivered a resounding victory for nuclear freeze.

Ronald Reagan fought us. The Pentagon fought us. The arms manufacturers fought us. Our Nuclear Freeze Resolution was narrowly defeated in the House. But the public rallied around this call for bold and urgent action.

On June 12, 1982‚Äîthe same day as the UN Special Session on Disarmament‚Äî1 million people stood with us to demand a nuclear freeze. That rally is still the largest peace protest in the history of the United States. The message we sent that day was clear: no more nukes.

In March of 1982, Randy and I partnered to introduce the Nuclear Freeze Resolution in the House of Representatives. By June, there was enough momentum around the nuclear freeze that one million people showed up in Central Park to protest Reagan‚Äôs nuclear buildup.

The Nuclear Freeze campaign was the idea of a brilliant woman named Randall Forsberg. It called for a halt on the production, deployment, and testing of nuclear weapons in the United States and the Soviet Union so we could prevent senseless nuclear catastrophe.

The arms race was the greatest existential threat our planet had ever faced. The US and USSR had enough atomic weapons to destroy the world a hundred times over. 

People were frightened. But across the country, people began to say enough is enough. We began to organize.

When Ronald Reagan took over as president, he suspended all negotiations with the Soviet Union over arms control and began to build an arsenal of nuclear weapons. The Soviet Union responded in kind. Before long, we were in a full blown nuclear arms race. https://t.co/ExMWSo3LB6

Qualified immunity forces victims and their families into an unjust Catch-22, with most cases dismissed outright. 

Many victims will not even try to make their case due to this impossible burden.

Today, victims of police violence cannot file suit unless they can identify a previous case where the use of force they suffered was ruled illegal. It must be in the same jurisdiction, the same context, and the same conduct.

Qualified immunity is not a law, but a judge-made doctrine designed to dismantle the Civil Rights Act of 1871 which allowed people to sue public officials, including police, who infringe on their fundamental rights.

Qualified immunity is one of the foremost tools of racist oppression. It is a legal doctrine that protects police from being sued and held liable by victims of police violence, effectively shielding officers from accountability.
